item.title: Security Was an Afterthought: The Quiet Failures at a Previous Job
item.description:
I recently changed jobs and moved to Berlin‚Äîwhich is another story in itself.

While getting everything set up for my new role, I noticed something. Several days after leaving my last job, I still had access to internal systems: Teams, VPN, project documentation, etc.

Which of course meant I still had access to a lot I definitely shouldn‚Äôt have.

Some Things That Still Haunt Me

  • No security cameras. Not even in places you’d expect, like entrances or the server room.

item.title: Interview Red Flags I‚Äôve Learned to Watch For
item.description:
Today I was thinking about interviews and the potential red flags to look out for. It’s something I‚Äôve come to care about a lot more, especially after working at a few companies where I probably should‚Äôve walked away before even starting.

Here‚Äôs a list, in no particular order, of things I‚Äôve noticed over the years:

  • Timesheets ‚Äì If they‚Äôre still doing manual timesheets, you‚Äôre probably in for micromanagement.
  • Outdated systems ‚Äì Like printing out forms or filling things by hand. Not a great sign.
  • “We‚Äôre like a family” ‚Äì Usually means cliques, favoritism, and zero boundaries.
  • “Everyone helps each other out” ‚Äì Translation: no clear responsibilities, lots of dumping.
  • “This person fills in because we don‚Äôt have that role” ‚Äì Sounds like understaffing.
  • “Fast-paced, tight deadlines” ‚Äì Often just means burnout.
  • MSPs (Managed Service Providers) ‚Äì Can be a red flag depending on their structure.
  • On-call expectations ‚Äì Especially if it‚Äôs vague or seems constant.
  • “We‚Äôre partners in everything” ‚Äì Buzzword soup. Often meaningless.
  • No technical assessment ‚Äì Worrying if it‚Äôs a technical role.
  • They look at your CV during the interview ‚Äì Means they‚Äôre unprepared.
  • Contradictory answers between rounds ‚Äì Test for consistency by asking the same question twice.
  • Low-energy or visibly unhappy interviewers ‚Äì People usually reflect the culture.
  • Aggressive or condescending interviewers ‚Äì Speaks for itself.
  • No help during technical questions ‚Äì The good ones support you through it.
  • Super long interviews ‚Äì Time management matters too.

item.title: Why I Chose Hugo (And Ditched Jekyll)
item.description:
When creating a blog, you‚Äôve got a ton of options. Some are just not as simple as Hugo. Hugo has its downsides, sure‚Äîbut for me, the pros easily outweigh the cons.

I tried Jekyll at first. The problem? Ruby dependencies. It got annoying fast. I didn‚Äôt feel like debugging stuff before I even got to the hard part: actually writing. Weird thing to say as someone in tech, maybe… but I‚Äôd rather save the troubleshooting for when it‚Äôs really needed.

item.title: Starting Again
item.description:
For me, I’m the type of person who says I’m starting something and means it… but actually seeing it through? That part tends to fall off.

I started a blog in the past, posted maybe once or twice, and that was that. Nothing really came of it.

But recently, I’ve been inspired again. A friend of mine, Chris, has been consistently posting content‚Äîmostly about Kubernetes and tech stuff he finds interesting. He even runs a YouTube channel. That’s probably not something I’ll be doing, but seeing his consistency sparked something.
